top_categories.workout_context: At mile 60 of 112, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
UCI Gravel World Championships' Gravel (70%), Paved roads (30%) forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 112 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic UCI Gravel World Championships' demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before October.
73ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
8,202ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
At UCI Gravel World Championships, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At UCI Gravel World Championships, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of UCI Gravel World Championships. Train it until it feels boring.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on varies by location—rolling technical terrain. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 112 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
8,202ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
112 miles rewards fat oxidation. This volume work shifts your fuel mix so you're still burning fat at hour 5, not bonking at hour 3.

race_overlay.heat: October in Rotating (2024: Heerlen, Netherlands) can bring heat. Complete 3–4 heat exposure sessions in the final 2 weeks before UCI Gravel World Championships. Increase sodium intake 48 hours before race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for UCI Gravel World Championships’s 112 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at UCI Gravel World Championships demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride varies by location—rolling technical terrain at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: gravel (70%), paved roads (30%), varies by location. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 112 miles.
